Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Documents and the Doing of Science: Studying Cyberinfrastructures in Use

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will build and validate a typology of collaboration types associated with cyberinfrastructure (CI) use in the conduct of science. The research focuses on documents and documenting practices as important windows into the socio-technical arrangements of scientific teams. A large number of virtual scientific collaborations will be studied and compared using a mix of text mining, social network analysis and qualitative methods. The research will result in: (1) a detailed compendium regarding what document infrastructures scientists build to support their virtual organizing and documenting practices and (2) specific design principles for the distributed, social and technical aspects of scientific work. The findings will have implications for better design and management of virtual scientific teams and for CI to support scientific endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work done on this project is in the pursuit of two goals. The first goal is to characterize how distributed scientific teams use documents as a means to understand collaboration. We theorize that using and producing documents are central activities of scientists, so understanding the ways in which teams of scientists develop, store, and use documentsprovides insight both into their collaboration and their uses of digital technologies. To this second point, and aware that practices, documents, people and their digital technologies are bound up together, using documents as a lens to better understand digital technologies uses and affordances (and by analysis needs and opportunities) provides opportunities for new insights.

Building on the primary and secondary data gathered from more than 100scientists, speaking on experiences with more than 200 research projects, combined with what is known from contemporary literature, through the five years of this project, we make three broad contributions to advancing distributed collaborations:

Contribution #1: Messiness is a core condition of distributed scientific collaboration. Data make clear that distributed scientific collaboration is a complex sociotechnical engagement. People, practices, goals, technologies, and interests change over time. Sometimes the changes are discrete (a person leaves the project), sometime slow changing (analyses lead to different directions), sometimes emergent (as when a new technology comes along that provides participants more support for interaction, or reshapes how they work with documents). This operational messiness is productive, even as it is uneven and takes more cognitive and social energy than might a defined workflow. It may be there are times when scientific collaboration is more or less messy. But, messiness is unavoidable. It also seems that messiness is useful in that its constant presence requires distributed scientific teams to negotiate and interact with one-another, creating stronger teams through this sociality. Another way to think of messiness is as a source of creative energy – the scientific enterprise is about imposing clarity and rationality, the collaborative effort to achieve this is not. 

Contribution #2: We advance the concept of collaborative parsimony as encompassing the sets of expectations and related social practices – at both the individual and collective level – that foster a productive and positive group effort. Collaborative parsimony is aspirational: participants in a collaboration want their shared effort succeed. Collaboration is pursued because the work to be done requires more skill, knowledge and ability than any one person possesses. Parsimony reflects the desire of each of the participants to alter their own work practices as little as possible in order to achieve the maximum collective value from workingtogether. Collaborative parsimony is about balancing the needs of working together withthe routines and practices that make each of us productive. Collaborative parsimony isa sociotechnical effort given that each participants personal and collaborative workpractices are bound up with digital platforms, software applications and means ofsharing and storing digital materials. 

Contribution #3:  We advance the concept of stabilization as a sociotechnical activity that demands extensive negotiations relative to the structure, form, uses and arrangements of digital materials. This contrasts with the more technocentric concept of standardization – or the reliance on technical standards to encourage interoperability among particular technologicalelements – as an organizing principle for assembling the digital resources supportingdistributed scientific collaboration. 

The document-centric research approach also made clear that the traditional focus on one unit of analysis often fall short when dealing with trace data.  Many scholars end up confusing the unit of data collection with the unit of analysis, or do not clearly distinguish what constitute sub-cases with their own unit of analysis from the larger case. To overcome these issues, we pursued this research using the concept of ‘lines of analysis.’ A line of analysis helps orient scholars to explore trace data and other document-centric research material by actively working across units of analysis. This process involves a constant comparison across the different analysis. In this way ‘lines of analysis’ provides an analytic frame that highlights the temporal nature of trace data and how analysis needs to consider not only its spatial but also the temporal boundaries.
